title: Conservation of angular momentum - spinning star

content.question: At time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, a hypothetical, spherical, uniformly-dense star of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> is spinning with constant angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> in deep space very far from any other objects. At a later time <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the star has mass <math alttext="uppercase M over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>M</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, radius <math alttext="uppercase R over 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>R</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, and angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The mass is lost as energy that moves away radially. The rotational inertia of a sphere of uniform density is given by <math alttext="I sub sphere equals, two fifths lowercase m, lowercase r squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>sphere</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, where <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is the mass of the sphere and <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> is the radius of the sphere. What is the ratio <math alttext="The ratio omega sub 1 to omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> ?
